  table td p { margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; }
</style>

Provides a resource to manage a GuardDuty detector.

> **NOTE:** Deleting this resource is equivalent to "disabling" GuardDuty for an AWS region, which removes all existing findings. You can set the `enable` attribute to `false` to instead "suspend" monitoring and feedback reporting while keeping existing data. See the [Suspending or Disabling Amazon GuardDuty documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/guardduty_suspend-disable.html) for more information.

> This content is derived from https://github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-aws/blob/master/website/docs/r/guardduty_detector.html.markdown.

The following arguments are supported:

<table class="ml-6">
    <thead>
        <tr>
            <th>Argument</th>
            <th>Type</th>
            <th>Description</th>
        </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
        <tr>
            <td class="align-top">enable</td>
            <td class="align-top"><code>boolean</code></td>
            <td class="align-top">{{% md %}}
(Optional) Enable monitoring and feedback reporting. Setting to `false` is equivalent to "suspending" GuardDuty. Defaults to `true`.

{{% /md %}}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
            <td class="align-top">finding<wbr>Publishing<wbr>Frequency</td>
            <td class="align-top"><code>string</code></td>
            <td class="align-top">{{% md %}}
(Optional) Specifies the frequency of notifications sent for subsequent finding occurrences. If the detector is a GuardDuty member account, the value is determined by the GuardDuty master account and cannot be modified, otherwise defaults to `SIX_HOURS`. For standalone and GuardDuty master accounts, it must be configured in this provider to enable drift detection. Valid values for standalone and master accounts: `FIFTEEN_MINUTES`, `ONE_HOUR`, `SIX_HOURS`. See [AWS Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/guardduty_findings_cloudwatch.html#guardduty_findings_cloudwatch_notification_frequency) for more information.

{{% /md %}}</td>
        </tr>
    </tbody>
</table>

The following output properties are available:

    <thead>
        <tr>
            <th>Argument</th>
            <th>Type</th>
            <th>Description</th>
        </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
        <tr>
            <td class="align-top">account<wbr>Id</td>
            <td class="align-top"><code>string</code></td>
            <td class="align-top">{{% md %}}
The AWS account ID of the GuardDuty detector

{{% /md %}}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
            <td class="align-top">enable</td>
            <td class="align-top"><code>boolean</code></td>
            <td class="align-top">{{% md %}}
Enable monitoring and feedback reporting. Setting to `false` is equivalent to "suspending" GuardDuty. Defaults to `true`.

{{% /md %}}</td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
            <td class="align-top">finding<wbr>Publishing<wbr>Frequency</td>
            <td class="align-top"><code>string</code></td>
            <td class="align-top">{{% md %}}
Specifies the frequency of notifications sent for subsequent finding occurrences. If the detector is a GuardDuty member account, the value is determined by the GuardDuty master account and cannot be modified, otherwise defaults to `SIX_HOURS`. For standalone and GuardDuty master accounts, it must be configured in this provider to enable drift detection. Valid values for standalone and master accounts: `FIFTEEN_MINUTES`, `ONE_HOUR`, `SIX_HOURS`. See [AWS Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/guardduty_findings_cloudwatch.html#guardduty_findings_cloudwatch_notification_frequency) for more information.

{{% /md %}}</td>
        </tr>
    </tbody>
</table>
